dt: {bc}a number that is one more than five {dx}see {dxt|Table of Numbers|number|table}{/dx}
{bc}the sixth in a set or series
{bc}something having six units or members: such as

et: Middle English, from {it}six{/it}, adjective, from Old English {it}siex{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}sehs{/it} six, Latin {it}sex{/it}, Greek {it}hex{/it}
shortdef: a number that is one more than five
the sixth in a set or series
something having six units or members: such as

et: from its having been the 606th compound tested and introduced by Paul Ehrlich †1915

dt: {bc}six bottles or cans (as of beer) packaged and purchased as a unit
{bc}a set of strong and well-defined abdominal muscles visible on a person's midsection

dt.t: In one room, a former Chicago Luvabulls dancer, chiseled {wi}six-pack{/wi} exposed in a crop top, gyrates to Beyonce's {ldquo}Deja Vu.{rdquo}

dt: often used in the phrase {it}six-pack abs{/it}

dt.t: I see so many people doing sit-ups and all these crunches trying to get {it}six-pack abs{/it}.

shortdef: six bottles or cans (as of beer) packaged and purchased as a unit
a set of strong and well-defined abdominal muscles visible on a person's midsection —often used in the phrase six-pack abs

dt: {bc}in the hundreds of thousands {bc}totaling 100,000 or more but less than one million

shortdef: in the hundreds of thousands : totaling 100,000 or more but less than one million

dt.t: legislators voting to {wi}deep-six{/wi} a government program

shortdef: to get rid of : discard, eliminate

dt: used especially in the phrase {it}give it the deep six{/it}

et: from the leadsman's call {it}by the deep six{/it} for a depth corresponding to the sixth deep on a sounding line
shortdef: a place of disposal or abandonment —used especially in the phrase give it the deep six

dt.t: "Beer here, barkeep," he said. "You're {wi}eighty-sixed{/wi}," Lucy said. "Cut off. No more for you."
I nodded at the corner bar beside us. He said, "I can't go in there." "Why?" "I'm {wi}eighty-sixed{/wi}."
He was {wi}eighty-sixed{/wi} from Twitter following outrage from other users …
The prof and his lovely wife … are ghosts, having recently been {wi}eighty-sixed{/wi} from this world when their car was hit by a falling rock.
But [Jim] Boylen is yesterday's news now, kicked to the curb, {wi}eighty-sixed{/wi} by the Bulls on Friday …

dt: {bc}to remove (an item) from a menu {bc}to no longer offer (an item) to customers

dt.t: Many small restaurants or bars may run into issues with their inventory. When there are not enough ingredients left to make a popular dish or drink, they'll have to {wi}86{/wi} it. This prevents customers from ordering it and then getting upset.

dt: {bc}to reject, discontinue, or get rid of (something)

dt.t: Democratic leaders also {wi}eighty-sixed{/wi} a similar amendment introduced in the House version of the bill …
Sadly, … the heartless bottom-liners on the food committee {wi}eighty-sixed{/wi} the black raspberry [ice cream] for good.
So after attempting a Zoom interview that had them sounding as garbled as the off-camera adults in a "Peanuts" special, we {wi}eighty-sixed{/wi} the audio on our computers and talked on the phone …

shortdef: to eject or ban (a customer); broadly : to eject, dismiss, or remove (someone)
to remove (an item) from a menu : to no longer offer (an item) to customers

et: from the stereotype of a six-pack of beer as a workingman's drink
shortdef: an ordinary man; specifically : a blue-collar worker
